title: Salford's mayor pledges extra money for city's poor as £16m cuts are approved
text:
Salford's mayor pledges extra money for city's poor as £16m cuts are approved "The government isn’t interested in Salford, so we have to do things for ourselves" Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now How Salford cuts will affect residents Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Salford’s mayor has pledged extra cash to stamp out poverty in the city - despite yet another round of brutal cuts. 
Paul Dennett launched a scathing attack on the Tories for leaving thousands of Salfordians destitute while those in leafy southern shires are protected. 
He said the city had found itself in ‘dire circumstances’ thanks to ‘vicious’ austerity measures, forced to make more cuts despite services already being ravaged. 
But he has still managed to find a bit of extra cash to help the poor. 
Mr Dennett, who claimed hunger, homelessness and poverty had ‘become the norm’ in Salford , announced a £3m drive to help the city’s most vulnerable people, including £2m for hundreds more affordable homes. Protesters outside Salford Civic Centre (Photo: Dominic Salter) 
He announced an extra £170,000 will be put into Salford’s credit union to tackle the scourge of loan sharks and payday lenders; £300,000 to support low-income residents in ‘crisis’; £70,000 for welfare rights and debt advice services; £10,000 extra for women suffering domestic abuse and violence; £33,000 to heat poor people’s homes; and £300,000 for youth services. 
Mr Dennett said the extra money was a ‘drop in the ocean’ considering the scale of the city’s poverty problem. 
Last week, the M.E.N. revealed that almost a quarter of the city’s children are living in poverty. Read More 
Thousands of people are struggling on low pay, facing rocketing house prices and rents, racking up crippling levels of debt. 
Some families are living on just £1.50 a DAY, according to a shock report. 
Cuts of £16m were rubber-stamped at Wednesday’s council budget meeting . But Mr Dennett still managed to find an extra £300,000 to keep Salford’s streets clean. 
Before the meeting, protesters gathered outside Salford Civic Centre to protest against cuts. Protesters outside Salford Civic Centre (Photo: Dominic Salter) 
Trade union bosses claimed certain measures would be devastating for staff and services. The families of disabled children also pleaded for a doomed care home to be saved. 
Mr Dennett’s first budget plan revolved around finding efficiencies, bringing in extra cash and reducing costs. Nearly £2m will be saved through the council’s link-up with NHS chiefs. Salford Mayor, Paul Dennett 
Despite Labour’s attempts to protect frontline services, some cuts - including to public health - were unavoidable. 
A 4.99 per cent council tax rise was also agreed. Some 3 pc of that will be ringfenced to prop up the city’s hard-hit social care services, which face a £2.3m black hole next year. 
But the extra cash, bosses say, will ‘barely scratch the service’. Unison branch secretary Steve North and protesters outside Salford Civic Centre (Photo: Dominic Salter) 
Cuts in Salford have now hit nearly £200m since 2010 - the equivalent of £64,000 being wiped from the books EVERY DAY. 
Some 200 care packages for those with special needs have been axed; 11 children’s centres shut; £1.2m taken from services for the homeless and elderly; work and skills support cash cut by 80 per cent; four youth centres closed; and nearly £20m taken out of children’s services - a 30 per cent reduction per head. Read More Campaigners launch last ditch effort to save children's home from closure 
Mr Dennett said town hall staff had been hit hard, with another 133 finding themselves out of job this year, and thousands of residents left on the breadline. 
He blasted the government over accusations it had offered Surrey council a ‘sweetheart deal’, claiming it was ‘Tory cronyism at its worst’. 
“There was no such deal on offer for Salford,” Mr Dennett added. Rebecca Howarth is leading the campaign to save the Grange care home (Photo: Dominic Salter) 
“The government isn’t interested in Salford, so clearly, we have to do things for ourselves. 
“The government has slashed our budgets, caused a collapse in vital services and now expect people to pay more in council tax to cover the crisis in social care costs. 
“Austerity and local government cuts are not working. Hunger and destitution has shockingly become the norm in Salford, as has debt and poverty. 
“We find ourselves in dire circumstances. Budget pressures are immense and the decisions we take are getting tougher and tougher. 
“But we will continue to fight for a better, fairer Salford.” Read More
